dict.string: Selection Sort uses a linear search to locate the smallest value in the unsorted list.
Selection Sort uses a linear search to locate the smallest value in the unsorted list.

Selection Sort uses a linear search to locate the smallest value in the unsorted list.
"0" is the smallest number.
Swap "0" with the left most number in the unsorted list.
"0" is now in the sorted sublist.
Linear search is used again to locate the smallest value in the remaining unsorted sublist.

"2" is the smallest number in the unsorted sublist.
Swap "2" with the left most number in the unsorted sublist.
Now, "2" is in the correct position in the sorted sublist.
Linear search is used again to locate the smallest value in the remaining unsorted sublist.

"3" is the smallest number in the unsorted sublist. Since "3" is already the left most number of the unsorted sublist. No swap is needed.
Now, "3" is in the correct position in the sorted sublist.
Linear search is used again to locate the smallest value in the remaining unsorted sublist.

"7" is the smallest number in the unsorted sublist. Since "7" is already the left most number of the unsorted sublist. No swap is needed.
Now, "7" is in the correct position in the sorted sublist. And "8" is the only number left in the unsorted sublist. Place "8" in to the right most position in the sorted sublist.
